translation.text: Shaloks Of Devotee Kabeer Jee:

section: Salok Bhagat Kabeer (Verses Of Saint Kabeer)

translation.text: One Universal Creator God. By The Grace Of The True Guru:

transliteration.text: ik ōunkār satigur prasād .

text: ਕਬੀਰ ਮੇਰੀ ਸਿਮਰਨੀ ਰਸਨਾ ਊਪਰਿ ਰਾਮੁ ॥
section: Salok Bhagat Kabeer (Verses Of Saint Kabeer)

translation.text: Kabeer, my rosary is my tongue, upon which the Lord's Name is strung.

transliteration.text: kabīr mērī simaranī rasanā ūpar rām .

melody.description: There is no melody or mood associated with this line, which may be because it is the preamble to the hymn, or is not meant to be read in any particular melody or mood

author.author: Saint Kabir
author.description:
Saint Kabir [1440 - 1518] was a Muslim mystic born in Varanasi in India, whose 541 hymns are included in the Guru Granth Sahib. His writings about God are full of love and devotion, very direct and striking in appeal.

The birth of Kabir remains to this day shrouded in mystery and legend. Authorities disagree on both when he was born and who his parents were. One legend proclaims a divine virginal birth. His mother was reputed to have been of the Brahman caste and to have become pregnant after a visit to a Hindu shrine.

Because she was unwed, she abandoned Kabir, who was found and adopted by a Muslim weaver. That his early life began as a Muslim there is no doubt, although he later became influenced by the Hindu ascetic, Ramananda, who he accepted as his Guru.

text: ਆਦਿ ਜੁਗਾਦੀ ਸਗਲ ਭਗਤ ਤਾ ਕੋ ਸੁਖੁ ਬਿਸ੍ਰਾਮੁ ॥੧॥
section: Salok Bhagat Kabeer (Verses Of Saint Kabeer)

translation.text: From the very beginning, and throughout the ages, all the devotees abide in tranquil peace. ||1||

transliteration.text: ād jugādī sagal bhagat tā kō sukh bisrām .1.

author.author: Saint Kabir
author.description:
Saint Kabir [1440 - 1518] was a Muslim mystic born in Varanasi in India, whose 541 hymns are included in the Guru Granth Sahib. His writings about God are full of love and devotion, very direct and striking in appeal.

The birth of Kabir remains to this day shrouded in mystery and legend. Authorities disagree on both when he was born and who his parents were. One legend proclaims a divine virginal birth. His mother was reputed to have been of the Brahman caste and to have become pregnant after a visit to a Hindu shrine.

Because she was unwed, she abandoned Kabir, who was found and adopted by a Muslim weaver. That his early life began as a Muslim there is no doubt, although he later became influenced by the Hindu ascetic, Ramananda, who he accepted as his Guru.

text: ਕਬੀਰ ਚੰਦਨ ਕਾ ਬਿਰਵਾ ਭਲਾ ਬੇੜ੍ਹਿਓ ਢਾਕ ਪਲਾਸ ॥
section: Salok Bhagat Kabeer (Verses Of Saint Kabeer)

translation.text: Kabeer, the sandalwood tree is good, even though it is surrounded by weeds.

transliteration.text: kabīr chandan kā biravā bhalā bērhiō dhāk palās .

melody.description: There is no melody or mood associated with this line, which may be because it is the preamble to the hymn, or is not meant to be read in any particular melody or mood

section: Salok Bhagat Kabeer (Verses Of Saint Kabeer)

translation.text: Those who dwell near the sandalwood tree, become just like the sandalwood tree. ||11||

transliteration.text: ōi bhī chandan hōi rahē basē j chandan pās .11.

section: Salok Bhagat Kabeer (Verses Of Saint Kabeer)

translation.text: Kabeer, the bamboo is drowned in its egotistical pride. No one should drown like this.

transliteration.text: kabīr bānhs badāī būdiā iu mat dūbah kōi .

section: Salok Bhagat Kabeer (Verses Of Saint Kabeer)

translation.text: Bamboo also dwells near the sandalwood tree, but it does not take up its fragrance. ||12||

transliteration.text: chandan kai nikatē basai bānhs sugandh n hōi .12.

section: Salok Bhagat Kabeer (Verses Of Saint Kabeer)

translation.text: Kabeer, the mortal loses his faith, for the sake of the world, but the world shall not go along with him in the end.

transliteration.text: kabīr dīn gavāiā dunī siu dunī n chālī sāth .

section: Salok Bhagat Kabeer (Verses Of Saint Kabeer)

translation.text: The idiot strikes his own foot with the axe by his own hand. ||13||

transliteration.text: pāi kuhārā māriā gāphal apunai hāth .13.

section: Salok Bhagat Kabeer (Verses Of Saint Kabeer)

translation.text: Kabeer, wherever I go, I see wonders everywhere.

transliteration.text: kabīr jah jah hau phiriō kautak thāō thāi .

section: Salok Bhagat Kabeer (Verses Of Saint Kabeer)

translation.text: But without the devotees of the One Lord, it is all wilderness to me. ||14||

transliteration.text: ik rām sanēhī bāharā ūjar mērai bhānhi .14.

section: Salok Bhagat Kabeer (Verses Of Saint Kabeer)

translation.text: Kabeer, the dwelling of the Saints is good; the dwelling of the unrighteous burns like an oven.

section: Salok Bhagat Kabeer (Verses Of Saint Kabeer)

translation.text: Those mansions in which the Lord's Name is not chanted might just as well burn down. ||15||

section: Salok Bhagat Kabeer (Verses Of Saint Kabeer)

translation.text: Kabeer, why cry at the death of a Saint? He is just going back to his home.

transliteration.text: kabīr sant mūē kiā rōīai jō apunē grih jāi .

section: Salok Bhagat Kabeer (Verses Of Saint Kabeer)

translation.text: Cry for the wretched, faithless cynic, who is sold from store to store. ||16||

translation.text: Kabeer, the faithless cynic is like a piece of garlic.

translation.text: Even if you eat it sitting in a corner, it becomes obvious to everyone. ||17||

translation.text: Kabeer, Maya is the butter-churn, and the breath is the churning-stick.

section: Salok Bhagat Kabeer (Verses Of Saint Kabeer)

translation.text: The Saints eat the butter, while the world drinks the whey. ||18||

translation.text: Whoever does the churning eats the butter; the others are just churning-sticks. ||19||

His mother was reputed to have been of the Brahman caste and to have become pregnant after a visit to a Hindu shrine.

Because she was unwed, she abandoned Kabir, who was found and adopted by a Muslim weaver. That his early life began as a Muslim there is no doubt, although he later became influenced by the Hindu ascetic, Ramananda, who he accepted as his Guru.

translation.text: Kabeer, peace does not come in this world by making lots of friends.

translation.text: Those who keep their consciousness focused on the One Lord shall find eternal peace. ||21||

translation.text: Kabeer, the world is afraid of death - that death fills my mind with bliss.

translation.text: There is no market to sell it, no appraiser, no customer, and no price. ||23||

author.description:
Saint Kabir [1440 - 1518] was a Muslim mystic born in Varanasi in India, whose 541 hymns are included in the Guru Granth Sahib. His writings about God are full of love and devotion, very direct and striking in appeal.

The birth of Kabir remains to this day shrouded in mystery and legend. Authorities disagree on both when he was born and who his parents were. One legend proclaims a divine virginal birth. His mother was reputed to have been of the Brahman caste and to have become pregnant after a visit to a Hindu shrine.

Because she was unwed, she abandoned Kabir, who was found and adopted by a Muslim weaver. That his early life began as a Muslim there is no doubt, although he later became influenced by the Hindu ascetic, Ramananda, who he accepted as his Guru.

text: ਕਬੀਰਾ ਤੁਹੀ ਕਬੀਰੁ ਤੂ ਤੇਰੋ ਨਾਉ ਕਬੀਰੁ ॥
section: Salok Bhagat Kabeer (Verses Of Saint Kabeer)

translation.text: Kabeer, you are Kabeer; your name means great.

transliteration.text: kabīrā tuhī kabīr tū tērō nāu kabīr .

melody.description: There is no melody or mood associated with this line, which may be because it is the preamble to the hymn, or is not meant to be read in any particular melody or mood

section: Salok Bhagat Kabeer (Verses Of Saint Kabeer)

translation.text: O Lord, You are Kabeer. The Jewel of the Lord is obtained, when the mortal first gives up his body. ||31||

section: Salok Bhagat Kabeer (Verses Of Saint Kabeer)

translation.text: Kabeer, do not struggle in stubborn pride; nothing happens just because you say so.

transliteration.text: kabīr jhankh n jhankhīai tumarō kahiō n hōi .

translation.text: No one can erase the actions of the Merciful Lord. ||32||

translation.text: Kabeer, no one who is false can withstand the Touchstone of the Lord.

section: Salok Bhagat Kabeer (Verses Of Saint Kabeer)

translation.text: He alone can pass the test of the Lord's Touchstone, who remains dead while yet alive. ||33||

translation.text: Without the Name of the One Lord, they are bound and gagged and taken to the City of Death. ||34||

translation.text: Those who are light get across, while those who carry the weight of their sins on their heads are drowned. ||35||

translation.text: Kabeer, let me remind you of this. Do not be skeptical or cynical.

translation.text: Kabeer, at first, I thought learning was good; then I thought Yoga was better.

translation.text: Kabeer, you have not shaved your mind, so why do you shave your head?

translation.text: Kabeer, do not abandon the Lord; your body and wealth shall go, so let them go.

translation.text: Kabeer, whatever sins the mortal has committed, he tries to keep hidden under cover.

His mother was reputed to have been of the Brahman caste and to have become pregnant after a visit to a Hindu shrine.

Because she was unwed, she abandoned Kabir, who was found and adopted by a Muslim weaver. That his early life began as a Muslim there is no doubt, although he later became influenced by the Hindu ascetic, Ramananda, who he accepted as his Guru.

author.description:
Saint Kabir [1440 - 1518] was a Muslim mystic born in Varanasi in India, whose 541 hymns are included in the Guru Granth Sahib. His writings about God are full of love and devotion, very direct and striking in appeal.

The birth of Kabir remains to this day shrouded in mystery and legend. Authorities disagree on both when he was born and who his parents were. One legend proclaims a divine virginal birth. His mother was reputed to have been of the Brahman caste and to have become pregnant after a visit to a Hindu shrine.

Because she was unwed, she abandoned Kabir, who was found and adopted by a Muslim weaver. That his early life began as a Muslim there is no doubt, although he later became influenced by the Hindu ascetic, Ramananda, who he accepted as his Guru.

text: ਕਬੀਰ ਚਰਨ ਕਮਲ ਕੀ ਮਉਜ ਕੋ ਕਹਿ ਕੈਸੇ ਉਨਮਾਨ ॥
section: Salok Bhagat Kabeer (Verses Of Saint Kabeer)

translation.text: Kabeer, how can I even describe the extent of the joy of the Lord's Lotus Feet?

transliteration.text: kabīr charan kamal kī mauj kō kah kaisē unamān .

section: Salok Bhagat Kabeer (Verses Of Saint Kabeer)

translation.text: I cannot describe its sublime glory; it has to be seen to be appreciated. ||121||

section: Salok Bhagat Kabeer (Verses Of Saint Kabeer)

translation.text: Kabeer, how can I describe what I have seen? No one will believe my words.

transliteration.text: kabīr dēkh kai kih kahau kahē n kō patīāi .

section: Salok Bhagat Kabeer (Verses Of Saint Kabeer)

translation.text: The Lord is just as He is. I dwell in delight, singing His Glorious Praises. ||122||

section: Salok Bhagat Kabeer (Verses Of Saint Kabeer)

translation.text: Kabeer, the flamingo pecks and feeds, and remembers her chicks. She pecks and pecks and feeds, and remembers them always. Her chicks are very dear to her, just like the love of wealth and Maya is dear to the mortal's mind. ||123||

translation.text: Kabeer, the sky is overcast and cloudy; the ponds and lakes are overflowing with water.

section: Salok Bhagat Kabeer (Verses Of Saint Kabeer)

translation.text: Kabeer, do not associate with the faithless cynics; run far away from them.

transliteration.text: kabīr sākat sang n kījīai dūrah jāīai bhāg .

melody.description: There is no melody or mood associated with this line, which may be because it is the preamble to the hymn, or is not meant to be read in any particular melody or mood

author.author: Saint Kabir
author.description:
Saint Kabir [1440 - 1518] was a Muslim mystic born in Varanasi in India, whose 541 hymns are included in the Guru Granth Sahib. His writings about God are full of love and devotion, very direct and striking in appeal.

The birth of Kabir remains to this day shrouded in mystery and legend. Authorities disagree on both when he was born and who his parents were. One legend proclaims a divine virginal birth. His mother was reputed to have been of the Brahman caste and to have become pregnant after a visit to a Hindu shrine.

Because she was unwed, she abandoned Kabir, who was found and adopted by a Muslim weaver. That his early life began as a Muslim there is no doubt, although he later became influenced by the Hindu ascetic, Ramananda, who he accepted as his Guru.

text: ਬਾਸਨੁ ਕਾਰੋ ਪਰਸੀਐ ਤਉ ਕਛੁ ਲਾਗੈ ਦਾਗੁ ॥੧੩੧॥
section: Salok Bhagat Kabeer (Verses Of Saint Kabeer)

translation.text: If you touch a vessel stained with soot, some of the soot will stick to you. ||131||

transliteration.text: bāsan kārō parasīai tau kash lāgai dāg .131.

translation.text: Kabeer, you have not contemplated the Lord, and now old age has overtaken you.

section: Salok Bhagat Kabeer (Verses Of Saint Kabeer)

translation.text: Now that the door of your mansion is on fire, what can you take out? ||132||

section: Salok Bhagat Kabeer (Verses Of Saint Kabeer)

translation.text: Kabeer, the fruit trees are bearing fruit, and the mangoes are becoming ripe.

section: Salok Bhagat Kabeer (Verses Of Saint Kabeer)

translation.text: Kabeer, some buy idols and worship them; in their stubborn-mindedness, they make pilgrimages to sacred shrines.

author.author: Saint Kabir
author.description:
Saint Kabir [1440 - 1518] was a Muslim mystic born in Varanasi in India, whose 541 hymns are included in the Guru Granth Sahib. His writings about God are full of love and devotion, very direct and striking in appeal.

The birth of Kabir remains to this day shrouded in mystery and legend. Authorities disagree on both when he was born and who his parents were. One legend proclaims a divine virginal birth. His mother was reputed to have been of the Brahman caste and to have become pregnant after a visit to a Hindu shrine.

Because she was unwed, she abandoned Kabir, who was found and adopted by a Muslim weaver. That his early life began as a Muslim there is no doubt, although he later became influenced by the Hindu ascetic, Ramananda, who he accepted as his Guru.

text: ਜਿਉ ਜਿਉ ਭਗਤਿ ਕਬੀਰ ਕੀ ਤਿਉ ਤਿਉ ਰਾਮ ਨਿਵਾਸ ॥੧੪੧॥
section: Salok Bhagat Kabeer (Verses Of Saint Kabeer)

translation.text: The more Kabeer worships Him, the more the Lord abides within his mind. ||141||

transliteration.text: jiu jiu bhagat kabīr kī tiu tiu rām nivās .141.

section: Salok Bhagat Kabeer (Verses Of Saint Kabeer)

translation.text: Kabeer, the mortal has fallen into the grip of family life, and the Lord has been set aside.

transliteration.text: kabīr gahagach pariō kutanb kai kānhthai rah gaiō rām .

melody.description: There is no melody or mood associated with this line, which may be because it is the preamble to the hymn, or is not meant to be read in any particular melody or mood

section: Salok Bhagat Kabeer (Verses Of Saint Kabeer)

translation.text: The messengers of the Righteous Judge of Dharma descend upon the mortal, in the midst of all his pomp and ceremony. ||142||

transliteration.text: āi parē dharam rāi kē bīchah dhūmā dhām .142.

section: Salok Bhagat Kabeer (Verses Of Saint Kabeer)

translation.text: Kabeer, even a pig is better than the faithless cynic; at least the pig keeps the village clean.

transliteration.text: kabīr sākat tē sūkar bhalā rākhai āshā gāu .

section: Salok Bhagat Kabeer (Verses Of Saint Kabeer)

translation.text: When the wretched, faithless cynic dies, no one even mentions his name. ||143||

section: Salok Bhagat Kabeer (Verses Of Saint Kabeer)

translation.text: Kabeer, the mortal gathers wealth, shell by shell, accumulating thousands and millions.

section: Salok Bhagat Kabeer (Verses Of Saint Kabeer)

translation.text: But when the time of his departure comes, he takes nothing at all with him. He is even stripped of his loin-cloth. ||144||

section: Salok Bhagat Kabeer (Verses Of Saint Kabeer)

translation.text: Kabeer, what good is it to become a devotee of Vishnu, and wear four malas?

section: Salok Bhagat Kabeer (Verses Of Saint Kabeer)

translation.text: On the outside, he may look like pure gold, but on the inside, he is stuffed with dust. ||145||

section: Salok Bhagat Kabeer (Verses Of Saint Kabeer)

translation.text: Kabeer, let yourself be a pebble on the path; abandon your egotistical pride.

transliteration.text: kabīr rōrā hōi rah bāt kā taj man kā abhimān .

section: Salok Bhagat Kabeer (Verses Of Saint Kabeer)

translation.text: Such a humble slave shall meet the Lord God. ||146||

section: Salok Bhagat Kabeer (Verses Of Saint Kabeer)

translation.text: Kabeer, what good would it be, to be a pebble? It would only hurt the traveller on the path.

translation.text: Your slave, O Lord, is like the dust of the earth. ||147||

translation.text: Kabeer, what then, if one could become dust? It is blown up by the wind, and sticks to the body.

translation.text: The banners wave above the lofty mansions, filled with gold and beautiful women.

section: Salok Bhagat Kabeer (Verses Of Saint Kabeer)

section: Salok Bhagat Kabeer (Verses Of Saint Kabeer)

translation.text: Kabeer, the wilderness is better than a city, if the Lord's devotees live there.

transliteration.text: kabīr pātan tē ūjar bhalā rām bhagat jih thāi .

melody.description: There is no melody or mood associated with this line, which may be because it is the preamble to the hymn, or is not meant to be read in any particular melody or mood

author.author: Saint Kabir
author.description:
Saint Kabir [1440 - 1518] was a Muslim mystic born in Varanasi in India, whose 541 hymns are included in the Guru Granth Sahib. His writings about God are full of love and devotion, very direct and striking in appeal.

The birth of Kabir remains to this day shrouded in mystery and legend. Authorities disagree on both when he was born and who his parents were. One legend proclaims a divine virginal birth. His mother was reputed to have been of the Brahman caste and to have become pregnant after a visit to a Hindu shrine.

Because she was unwed, she abandoned Kabir, who was found and adopted by a Muslim weaver. That his early life began as a Muslim there is no doubt, although he later became influenced by the Hindu ascetic, Ramananda, who he accepted as his Guru.

text: ਰਾਮ ਸਨੇਹੀ ਬਾਹਰਾ ਜਮ ਪੁਰੁ ਮੇਰੇ ਭਾਂਇ ॥੧੫੧॥
section: Salok Bhagat Kabeer (Verses Of Saint Kabeer)

translation.text: Without my Beloved Lord, it is like the City of Death for me. ||151||

transliteration.text: rām sanēhī bāharā jam pur mērē bhānhi .151.

translation.text: Kabeer, between the Ganges and Jamunaa Rivers, on the shore of Celestial Silence,

section: Salok Bhagat Kabeer (Verses Of Saint Kabeer)

translation.text: Kabeer, I saw a strange and wonderful thing. A jewel was being sold in a store.

transliteration.text: kabīrā ēk achanbhau dēkhiō hīrā hāt bikāi .

section: Salok Bhagat Kabeer (Verses Of Saint Kabeer)

translation.text: Kabeer, where there is spiritual wisdom, there is righteousness and Dharma. Where there is falsehood, there is sin.

translation.text: Where there is greed, there is death. Where there is forgiveness, there is God Himself. ||155||

translation.text: Kabeer, what good is it to give up Maya, if the mortal does not give up his pride?

translation.text: Even the silent sages and seers are destroyed by pride; pride eats up everything. ||156||

translation.text: The blind do not take in any of His Teachings; it is as useless as blowing into bamboo. ||158||

translation.text: Kabeer, why do you slander the wife of the king? Why do you honor the slave of the Lord?

section: Salok Bhagat Kabeer (Verses Of Saint Kabeer)

translation.text: The True Guru has given me courage. Kabeer, I have purchased the diamond, on the banks of the Mansarovar Lake. ||161||

section: Salok Bhagat Kabeer (Verses Of Saint Kabeer)

translation.text: As soon as an appraiser is found, the price of the jewel is set. ||162||

translation.text: Kabeer, you remember the Lord in meditation, only when the need arises. You should remember Him all the time.

section: Salok Bhagat Kabeer (Verses Of Saint Kabeer)

translation.text: You shall dwell in the city of immortality, and the Lord shall restore the wealth you lost. ||163||

translation.text: Kabeer, it is good to perform selfless service for two - the Saints and the Lord.

translation.text: The Lord is the Giver of liberation, and the Saint inspires us to chant the Naam. ||164||

translation.text: Kabeer, the crowds follow the path which the Pandits, the religious scholars, have taken.

section: Salok Bhagat Kabeer (Verses Of Saint Kabeer)

translation.text: There is a difficult and treacherous cliff on that path to the Lord; Kabeer is climbing that cliff. ||165||

translation.text: Kabeer, the mortal dies of his worldly troubles and pain, after worrying about his family.

section: Salok Bhagat Kabeer (Verses Of Saint Kabeer)

His mother was reputed to have been of the Brahman caste and to have become pregnant after a visit to a Hindu shrine.

Because she was unwed, she abandoned Kabir, who was found and adopted by a Muslim weaver. That his early life began as a Muslim there is no doubt, although he later became influenced by the Hindu ascetic, Ramananda, who he accepted as his Guru.

His mother was reputed to have been of the Brahman caste and to have become pregnant after a visit to a Hindu shrine.

Because she was unwed, she abandoned Kabir, who was found and adopted by a Muslim weaver. That his early life began as a Muslim there is no doubt, although he later became influenced by the Hindu ascetic, Ramananda, who he accepted as his Guru.

translation.text: Kabeer, those who do not know anything, pass their lives in peaceful sleep.

translation.text: But I have understood the riddle; I am faced with all sorts of troubles. ||181||

section: Salok Bhagat Kabeer (Verses Of Saint Kabeer)

translation.text: Kabeer, those who are beaten cry a lot; but the cries of the pain of separation are different.

section: Salok Bhagat Kabeer (Verses Of Saint Kabeer)

translation.text: Struck by the Mystery of God, Kabeer remains silent. ||182||

translation.text: Kabeer, the stroke of a lance is easy to bear; it takes away the breath.

section: Salok Bhagat Kabeer (Verses Of Saint Kabeer)

translation.text: But one who endures the stroke of the Word of the Shabad is the Guru, and I am his slave. ||183||

translation.text: Kabeer: O Mullah, why do you climb to the top of the minaret? The Lord is not hard of hearing.

translation.text: Why does the Shaykh bother to go on pilgrimage to Mecca, if he is not content with himself?

author.author: Saint Kabir
author.description:
Saint Kabir [1440 - 1518] was a Muslim mystic born in Varanasi in India, whose 541 hymns are included in the Guru Granth Sahib. His writings about God are full of love and devotion, very direct and striking in appeal.

The birth of Kabir remains to this day shrouded in mystery and legend. Authorities disagree on both when he was born and who his parents were. One legend proclaims a divine virginal birth. His mother was reputed to have been of the Brahman caste and to have become pregnant after a visit to a Hindu shrine.

Because she was unwed, she abandoned Kabir, who was found and adopted by a Muslim weaver. That his early life began as a Muslim there is no doubt, although he later became influenced by the Hindu ascetic, Ramananda, who he accepted as his Guru.

text: ਕਬੀਰ ਰਾਮੈ ਰਾਮ ਕਹੁ ਕਹਿਬੇ ਮਾਹਿ ਬਿਬੇਕ ॥
section: Salok Bhagat Kabeer (Verses Of Saint Kabeer)

translation.text: Kabeer, use the word 'Raam', only to speak of the All-pervading Lord. You must make that distinction.

transliteration.text: kabīr rāmai rām kah kahibē māh bibēk .

melody.description: There is no melody or mood associated with this line, which may be because it is the preamble to the hymn, or is not meant to be read in any particular melody or mood

section: Salok Bhagat Kabeer (Verses Of Saint Kabeer)

translation.text: One 'Raam' is pervading everywhere, while the other is contained only in himself. ||191||

transliteration.text: ēk anēkah mil gaiā ēk samānā ēk .191.

melody.description: There is no melody or mood associated with this line, which may be because it is the preamble to the hymn, or is not meant to be read in any particular melody or mood

section: Salok Bhagat Kabeer (Verses Of Saint Kabeer)

translation.text: Kabeer, those houses in which neither the Holy nor the Lord are served

transliteration.text: kabīr jā ghar sādh n sēvīah har kī sēvā nāh .

translation.text: - those houses are like cremation grounds; demons dwell within them. ||192||

translation.text: Kabeer, I have become mute, insane and deaf.

section: Salok Bhagat Kabeer (Verses Of Saint Kabeer)

translation.text: I am crippled - the True Guru has pierced me with His Arrow. ||193||

transliteration.text: pāvah tē pingul bhaiā māriā satigur bān .193.

section: Salok Bhagat Kabeer (Verses Of Saint Kabeer)

translation.text: Kabeer, the True Guru, the Spiritual Warrior, has shot me with His Arrow.

transliteration.text: kabīr satigur sūramē bāhiā bān j ēk .

section: Salok Bhagat Kabeer (Verses Of Saint Kabeer)

translation.text: As soon as it struck me, I fell to the ground, with a hole in my heart. ||194||

translation.text: Kabeer, the pure drop of water falls from the sky, onto the dirty ground.

translation.text: You must acknowledge this, that without the Sangat, the Holy Congregation, it turns into burnt ashes. ||195||

section: Salok Bhagat Kabeer (Verses Of Saint Kabeer)

translation.text: Millions of clever people may try, but they will fail - it cannot be made separate again. ||196||

section: Salok Bhagat Kabeer (Verses Of Saint Kabeer)

translation.text: Kabeer, I was going on a pilgrimage to Mecca, and God met me on the way.

section: Salok Bhagat Kabeer (Verses Of Saint Kabeer)

translation.text: He scolded me and asked, "Who told you that I am only there?"||197||

section: Salok Bhagat Kabeer (Verses Of Saint Kabeer)

translation.text: Kabeer, I went to Mecca - how many times, Kabeer?

section: Salok Bhagat Kabeer (Verses Of Saint Kabeer)

translation.text: O Lord, what is the problem with me? You have not spoken to me with Your Mouth. ||198||

section: Salok Bhagat Kabeer (Verses Of Saint Kabeer)

translation.text: Kabeer, they oppress living beings and kill them, and call it proper.

transliteration.text: kabīr jī j mārah jōr kar kahatē hah j halāl .

section: Salok Bhagat Kabeer (Verses Of Saint Kabeer)

translation.text: When the Lord calls for their account, what will their condition be? ||199||

translation.text: Kabeer, it is tyranny to use force; the Lord shall call you to account.

author.author: Saint Kabir
author.description:
Saint Kabir [1440 - 1518] was a Muslim mystic born in Varanasi in India, whose 541 hymns are included in the Guru Granth Sahib. His writings about God are full of love and devotion, very direct and striking in appeal.

The birth of Kabir remains to this day shrouded in mystery and legend. Authorities disagree on both when he was born and who his parents were. One legend proclaims a divine virginal birth. His mother was reputed to have been of the Brahman caste and to have become pregnant after a visit to a Hindu shrine.

Because she was unwed, she abandoned Kabir, who was found and adopted by a Muslim weaver. That his early life began as a Muslim there is no doubt, although he later became influenced by the Hindu ascetic, Ramananda, who he accepted as his Guru.

text: ਕਬੀਰ ਲੇਖਾ ਦੇਨਾ ਸੁਹੇਲਾ ਜਉ ਦਿਲ ਸੂਚੀ ਹੋਇ ॥
section: Salok Bhagat Kabeer (Verses Of Saint Kabeer)

translation.text: Kabeer, it is easy to render your account, if your heart is pure.

transliteration.text: kabīr lēkhā dēnā suhēlā jau dil sūchī hōi .

translation.text: In the True Court of the Lord, no one will seize you. ||201||

translation.text: The six Shaastras and the eighty-four Siddhas are entrenched in skepticism. ||202||

translation.text: Kabeer, nothing is mine within myself. Whatever there is, is Yours, O Lord.

section: Salok Bhagat Kabeer (Verses Of Saint Kabeer)

translation.text: If I surrender to You what is already Yours, what does it cost me? ||203||

section: Salok Mehla 3 (Verses Of Guru Amar Das)

translation.text: God Himself makes the mortals anxious, and He Himself takes the anxiety away.

transliteration.text: chintā bh āp karāisī achint bh āpē dēi .

author.author: Guru Amar Das
author.description:
Guru Amar Das [1479 - 1574] was the third Guru of the Sikhs, born at Basarke in Amritsar. His father, Tej Bhan and mother Bakht Kaur were orthodox Hindus. He became the oldest Sikh Guru.

Guru Amar Das put an end to tradition of sati, the burning of the widow on her husbands funeral pyre, and encouraged the remarriage of widows. He opened 22 preaching centres called Manjees and founded the town of Goindwal as the headquarters for the Sikh community.

text: ਨਾਨਕ ਸੋ ਸਾਲਾਹੀਐ ਜਿ ਸਭਨਾ ਸਾਰ ਕਰੇਇ ॥੨੨੦॥
section: Salok Mehla 3 (Verses Of Guru Amar Das)

translation.text: O Nanak, praise the One, who takes care of all. ||220||

section: Salok Bhagat Kabeer (Verses Of Saint Kabeer)

translation.text: Kabeer, the mortal does not remember the Lord; he wanders around, engrossed in greed.

transliteration.text: kabīr rām n chētiō phiriā lālach māh .

melody.description: There is no melody or mood associated with this line, which may be because it is the preamble to the hymn, or is not meant to be read in any particular melody or mood

author.author: Saint Kabir
author.description:
Saint Kabir [1440 - 1518] was a Muslim mystic born in Varanasi in India, whose 541 hymns are included in the Guru Granth Sahib. His writings about God are full of love and devotion, very direct and striking in appeal.

The birth of Kabir remains to this day shrouded in mystery and legend. Authorities disagree on both when he was born and who his parents were. One legend proclaims a divine virginal birth. His mother was reputed to have been of the Brahman caste and to have become pregnant after a visit to a Hindu shrine.

Because she was unwed, she abandoned Kabir, who was found and adopted by a Muslim weaver. That his early life began as a Muslim there is no doubt, although he later became influenced by the Hindu ascetic, Ramananda, who he accepted as his Guru.

text: ਪਾਪ ਕਰੰਤਾ ਮਰਿ ਗਇਆ ਅਉਧ ਪੁਨੀ ਖਿਨ ਮਾਹਿ ॥੨੨੧॥
section: Salok Bhagat Kabeer (Verses Of Saint Kabeer)

translation.text: Committing sins, he dies, and his life ends in an instant. ||221||

transliteration.text: pāp karantā mar gaiā audh punī khin māh .221.

The birth of Kabir remains to this day shrouded in mystery and legend. Authorities disagree on both when he was born and who his parents were. One legend proclaims a divine virginal birth. His mother was reputed to have been of the Brahman caste and to have become pregnant after a visit to a Hindu shrine.

Because she was unwed, she abandoned Kabir, who was found and adopted by a Muslim weaver. That his early life began as a Muslim there is no doubt, although he later became influenced by the Hindu ascetic, Ramananda, who he accepted as his Guru.

text: ਕਬੀਰ ਜਉ ਤੁਹਿ ਸਾਧ ਪਿਰੰਮ ਕੀ ਪਾਕੇ ਸੇਤੀ ਖੇਲੁ ॥
section: Salok Bhagat Kabeer (Verses Of Saint Kabeer)

translation.text: Kabeer, if you desire to play the game of love with the Lord, play it with someone with committment.

transliteration.text: kabīr jau tuh sādh piranm kī pākē sētī khēl .

melody.description: There is no melody or mood associated with this line, which may be because it is the preamble to the hymn, or is not meant to be read in any particular melody or mood

Because she was unwed, she abandoned Kabir, who was found and adopted by a Muslim weaver. That his early life began as a Muslim there is no doubt, although he later became influenced by the Hindu ascetic, Ramananda, who he accepted as his Guru.

text: ਕਾਚੀ ਸਰਸਉਂ ਪੇਲਿ ਕੈ ਨਾ ਖਲਿ ਭਈ ਨ ਤੇਲੁ ॥੨੪੦॥
section: Salok Bhagat Kabeer (Verses Of Saint Kabeer)

translation.text: Pressing the unripe mustard seeds produces neither oil nor flour. ||240||

transliteration.text: kāchī sarasaunh pēl kai nā khal bhaī n tēl .240.

melody.description: There is no melody or mood associated with this line, which may be because it is the preamble to the hymn, or is not meant to be read in any particular melody or mood

text: ਢੂੰਢਤ ਡੋਲਹਿ ਅੰਧ ਗਤਿ ਅਰੁ ਚੀਨਤ ਨਾਹੀ ਸੰਤ ॥
section: Salok Bhagat Kabeer (Verses Of Saint Kabeer)

translation.text: Searching, the mortal stumbles like a blind person, and does not recognize the Saint.

transliteration.text: dhūndhat dōlah andh gat ar chīnat nāhī sant .

melody.description: There is no melody or mood associated with this line, which may be because it is the preamble to the hymn, or is not meant to be read in any particular melody or mood

text: ਕਹਿ ਨਾਮਾ ਕਿਉ ਪਾਈਐ ਬਿਨੁ ਭਗਤਹੁ ਭਗਵੰਤੁ ॥੨੪੧॥
section: Salok Bhagat Kabeer (Verses Of Saint Kabeer)

translation.text: Says Naam Dayv, how can one obtain the Lord God, without His devotee? ||241||

transliteration.text: kah nāmā kiu pāīai bin bhagatah bhagavant .241.

melody.description: There is no melody or mood associated with this line, which may be because it is the preamble to the hymn, or is not meant to be read in any particular melody or mood

section: Salok Bhagat Kabeer (Verses Of Saint Kabeer)

translation.text: Forsaking the Diamond of the Lord, the mortals put their hopes in another.

transliteration.text: har sō hīrā shād kai karah ān kī ās .

melody.description: There is no melody or mood associated with this line, which may be because it is the preamble to the hymn, or is not meant to be read in any particular melody or mood

text: ਤੇ ਨਰ ਦੋਜਕ ਜਾਹਿਗੇ ਸਤਿ ਭਾਖੈ ਰਵਿਦਾਸ ॥੨੪੨॥
section: Salok Bhagat Kabeer (Verses Of Saint Kabeer)

translation.text: Those people shall go to hell; Ravi Daas speaks the Truth. ||242||

transliteration.text: tē nar dōjak jāhigē sat bhākhai ravidās .242.

melody.description: There is no melody or mood associated with this line, which may be because it is the preamble to the hymn, or is not meant to be read in any particular melody or mood

section: Salok Bhagat Kabeer (Verses Of Saint Kabeer)

translation.text: Kabeer, if you live the householder's life, then practice righteousness; otherwise, you might as well retire from the world.

transliteration.text: kabīr jau grih karah t dharam kar nāhī t kar bairāg .

melody.description: There is no melody or mood associated with this line, which may be because it is the preamble to the hymn, or is not meant to be read in any particular melody or mood

text: ਬੈਰਾਗੀ ਬੰਧਨੁ ਕਰੈ ਤਾ ਕੋ ਬਡੋ ਅਭਾਗੁ ॥੨੪੩॥
section: Salok Bhagat Kabeer (Verses Of Saint Kabeer)

translation.text: If someone renounces the world, and then gets involved in worldly entanglements, he shall suffer terrible misfortune. ||243||

transliteration.text: bairāgī bandhan karai tā kō badō abhāg .243.
